p.text: [Heading subst Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]
[Heading subst Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 111] s 111 Appointment of associate Judges and acting associate Judges

leg:heading.title: Appointment of associate Judges and acting associate Judges

p.text: The Governor may appoint one or more associate Judges.
[subs (1) am Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]
The Governor may appoint one or more acting associate Judges.
[subs (2) am Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]
Each person so appointed is to be a person who:
holds or has held a judicial office of this State or of the Commonwealth, another State or a Territory; or
is an Australian lawyer of at least 5 years' standing.
[subs (3) subst Act 7 of 2002 Sch 1; am Act 120 of 2006 s 3 and Sch 3[3.25] , effective 4 December 2006]
[subs (4) rep Act 87 of 1993 s 4 and Sch 5]
A registrar may, if qualified in accordance with subsections (3) and (4) , be appointed an acting associate Judge and, if so appointed, may retain his or her office as registrar.
[subs (5) am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3; Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]

A retired associate Judge may be appointed under subsection (2) as an acting associate Judge even though the retired associate Judge has reached the age of 72 years (or will have reached that age before the appointment expires), but may not be so appointed for any period that extends beyond the day on which he or she reaches the age of 75 years.
[subs (6) insrt Act 10 of 1988 s 3 and Sch 1 ; am Act 169 of 1989 s 3 and Sch 8(2) ; Act 56 of 1990 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]
[s 111 am Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]

The appointment of a person to the office of associate Judge or acting associate Judge shall, subject to this Division, be on such terms and conditions (except as to remuneration or pension) as may be specified in the instrument of the person's appointment or as may be agreed by the Governor and the officer.
[subs (1) am Act 69 of 1972 s 4 ; Act 4 of 1976 s 28 and Sch 5 ; Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3 ; Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]
An associate Judge or acting associate Judge is entitled to be paid—
remuneration in accordance with the Statutory and Other Offices Remuneration Act 1975 ; and
such travelling and subsistence allowances as the Minister may from time to time determine in respect of the associate Judge or acting associate Judge.
[subs (2) insrt Act 4 of 1976 s 28 and Sch 5 ; am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3 ; Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 113] s 113 Public Sector Employment and Management Act 2002

leg:heading.title: Public Sector Employment and Management Act 2002

p.text: The Public Sector Employment and Management Act 2002 does not apply to an associate Judge.

Despite subsection (1), if the Public Sector Employment and Management Act 2002 applies to a person immediately before the person’s appointment as associate Judge, the person is entitled to receive any deferred or extended leave and any privileges as if the person had remained an officer within the meaning of that Act.

The Public Sector Employment and Management Act 2002 does not apply to an acting associate Judge unless that Act applies to the acting associate Judge immediately before his or her appointment as acting associate Judge.
[s 113 subst Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]
The Superannuation Act 1916 , shall not apply to an associate Judge.
[subs (1) am Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]
Where an associate Judge is at the time of the associate Judge's appointment as master a contributor or pensioner under the Superannuation Act 1916 —

there shall be paid to the associate Judge out of the State Superannuation Fund a sum equal to the contributions paid by the associate Judge to the fund after deducting the sum of any payments to the associate Judge of pension under that Act, but without interest; and
the associate Judge shall not, nor shall any spouse, de facto partner or child of the associate Judge's, be entitled to receive any other payment or pension under that Act.
“De facto partner” is defined in section 21C of the Interpretation Act 1987.

[subs (2) am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3 ; Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005; Act 23 of 2008 s 5 and Sch 3.44[1], effective 22 September 2008 ; Act 19 of 2010 Sch 3.108[1], effective 19 May 2010]

The Superannuation Act 1916 , shall not apply to an acting associate judge unless that Act applies to the acting associate Judge immediately before the acting associate Judge's appointment as acting associate Judge.
[subs (3) am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3 ; Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]
[Repealed]
[subs (4) rep Act 19 of 2010 Sch 3.108[2], effective 19 May 2010]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 115] s 115 Resignation and tenure of associate Judges and acting associate Judges

leg:heading.title: Resignation and tenure of associate Judges and acting associate Judges

p.text: An associate Judge or an acting associate Judge may—
resign from office by instrument in writing; or
[repealed]
[subs (1) am Act 100 of 1986 s 55 and Sch 4 ; Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3 ; Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]
[subs (2) rep Act 100 of 1986 s 55 and Sch 4]
An acting associate Judge shall, subject to subsection (1) , hold office for such term as the Governor may specify in the instrument of the acting associate Judge's appointment.
[subs (3) am Act 10 of 1988 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3 ; Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]
Except as provided by section 111(6) , the term for which an acting associate Judge holds office shall not extend beyond the day on which the associate Judge reaches the age of 72 years.
[subs (4) insrt Act 10 of 1988 s 3 and Sch 1 ; am Act 56 of 1990 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]
[s 115 am Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]
The Governor may—
assign an associate Judge or an acting associate Judge—
to the Court of Appeal;
to the Court of Appeal and any one or more Divisions; or
to any one or more Divisions; and
revoke an assignment of an associate Judge or acting associate Judge to the Court of Appeal or to any Division.
[s 116 subst Act 41 of 1972 s 10 ; am Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]

Where two or more associate Judges are assigned to the Court of Appeal or to any Division, they shall, subject to the terms of any instrument of assignment, have seniority amongst themselves in accordance with the order of their assignments to the Court of Appeal, or to that Division, as the case may be.
[s 117 am Act 41 of 1972 s 10 ; Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 117A] s 117A Powers: associate Judge in Court of Appeal

leg:heading.title: Powers: associate Judge in Court of Appeal

p.text: In this section associate Judge in the Court of Appeal means an associate Judge or acting associate Judge assigned to the Court of Appeal or an associate Judge or acting associate Judge directed by the Chief Justice to act in the Court of Appeal.
[subs (1) subst Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]

An associate Judge in the Court of Appeal may exercise such powers of the Court of Appeal (and only such powers) as are exercisable by a Judge of Appeal under section 46 and are, by or under this or any other Act, conferred upon an associate Judge assigned to the Court of Appeal.
[subs (2) am Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]
A judgment given or an order made by an associate Judge in the Court of Appeal may be discharged or varied by the Court of Appeal.
[subs (3) am Act 226 of 1989 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]

Subject to subsection (3) , a judgment given or an order made or direction given by an associate Judge in the Court of Appeal shall have effect as a judgment or order or direction of the Court of Appeal, whether or not the judgment, order or direction is within the powers mentioned in this section of an associate Judge in the Court of Appeal.
[subs (4) am Act 226 of 1989 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]
An associate Judge in the Court of Appeal shall constitute the Court of Appeal for the purpose of the exercise of the powers mentioned in subsection (2) .
[subs (5) am Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]
[s 117A insrt Act 41 of 1972 s 10 ; am Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]
Legislation cited in [SCA s 117A.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 117A.
There is no associate Judge appointed under s 117A in the Court of Appeal.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 118] s 118 Powers: divisional associate Judge

p.text: In this section, divisional associate Judge means, in relation to any Division, an associate Judge or acting associate Judge assigned to the Division or an associate Judge or acting associate Judge directed by the Chief Justice to act in the Division.
[subs (1) subst Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]

A divisional associate Judge may exercise such powers of the Court in the Division (and only such powers) as are, by or under this or any other Act, conferred upon an associate Judge assigned to the Division.
[subs (2) am Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]
A judgment given or an order made by a divisional associate Judge in any Division may be set aside or varied by the Court.
[subs (3) am Act 226 of 1989 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]

Subject to subsection (3) , a judgment given or an order made or direction given by a divisional associate Judge in any Division shall have effect as a judgment or order or direction of the Court in the Division, whether or not the judgment, order or direction is within the powers mentioned in this section of the divisional associate Judge.
[subs (4) am Act 226 of 1989 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]
A divisional associate Judge in any Division shall constitute the Court in that Division for the purpose of the exercise of the powers mentioned in subsection (2) .
[subs (5) am Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 6, effective 15 June 2005]
[s 118 subst Act 41 of 1972 s 10 ; am Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 118.5] Associate judge constitutes the court

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 118.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 118(2), (5), s 75A, s 75A(1).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 49.4.

The effect of s 118(2) and (5) is to “make” clear that a divisional associate judge may only exercise the powers expressly conferred under the Act and rules even though an associate judge falls within the definition of the “court” in SCA s 25: see generally [SCR 60.1A.2] . As a consequence, any appeal from an associate judge to a single judge (in accordance with r 49.4 of the UCPR) is an appeal “in proceedings in the Court” for the purpose of s 75A(1) and is subject to the provisions of s 75A . It follows that such an appeal is by way of rehearing: Do Carmo v Ford Excavations Pty Ltd [1981] 1 NSWLR 409.
Legislation cited in [SCA s 118.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 Pt 60, Sch D.

The powers of the associate judges are found in Pt 60 of the Supreme Court Rules and, more particularly, in Sch D . In general, the Rules confer on associate judges similar powers to those exercisable by a judge of the court, subject to any limitation set out in Sch D . Associate judges may also exercise the incidental, but not the inherent powers of the court: see [SCR 60.1A.3] .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 118.15] Nature of the court's power to set aside or vary associate judge's orders

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 118.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 49, UCPR r 49.20, UCPR rr 49.7A–49.13, UCPR r 51.2, UCPR r 51.58, UCPR r 51.59.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 Pt 60.

heading.title: Nature of the court's power to set aside or vary associate judge's orders

p.text: The power of variation conferred by s 118(3) reflects wording contained in ss 46(4) , 117A(3) and 121(3) of the SCA. The review power in s 118(3) was included in the Act following recommendations in the Law Reform Commission Report (1971) LRC 14. Various provisions of the rules make it clear that the power to review conferred by ss 46(4) and 117A(3) was intended to be distinct from the power to make orders on appeal. For example, s 19(2) of the Act and UCPR r 51.2 defines “appeal” as excluding an application for review; and UCPR r 51.58 prescribes the time limit for review applications under s 46(4) . However, as Dunford J observed in Gill v Residential Tribunal (2001) 53 NSWLR 425; [2001] NSWSC 896; BC200106500 at [16] , SCR Pt 60 did not (and Pt 49 of the UCPR does not) contain any procedure for an application to review an associate judge's decision (compare UCPR r 49.20 relating to review of a registrar's decision) and the appeal provisions in UCPR rr 49.7A–49.13 implicitly assume that the rights of appeal those rules confer represent the exclusive procedure for challenging an associate judge's decision. Consistent with that implication, in Avard v Harrison (NSWSC, McLelland J, No 5137/89, 13 July 1989, unreported, BC8901965) McLelland J held that an appeal was the preferable procedure for the review of an associate judge's decision. And in Gill v Residential Tribunal , above, Dunford J held that, at least where proceedings were specifically referred to an associate judge as constituting the court, s 118(3) did not confer a separate right of appeal or review: see also Koutsourais v Metledge [2003] NSWSC 416; BC200302414 (semble no review power where the associate judge's irregular exercise of jurisdiction only operated because of s 118(4) ). In Gill's case, above, Dunford J approved the distinction, drawn by Windeyer J in Pollicino v Pollicino (NSWSC, Windeyer J, No 3801/97, 14 August 1997, unreported, BC9703590) between instances where the associate judge exercised “the power of the court pursuant to a jurisdiction given pursuant to the rules” and those where an associate judge's decision was “as a delegate of a judge”. The practical result of these decisions is to limit the scope of the review power in s 118(3) to cases of the latter kind: (compare the approach taken to the review of decisions of the registrar of the Court of Appeal under UCPR r 51.59 and by reference to UCPR Pt 49 ). As to the nature of the review power and the principles governing its exercise: see [49.19.5] .
